g.text: Struct padding is a mechanism that most compilers use to optimize
memory access and alignment within data structures. On a 32-bit
architecture, each field in a struct is typically aligned on an
address boundary equal to its own size or the compiler’s default
alignment setting. For example, an int might need to be aligned on
a 4-byte boundary. When the compiler inserts padding, it places
unused bytes between fields so that each field starts at an
address boundary optimal for the target processor. This helps the
CPU fetch data more efficiently. However, it also means the overall
structure might occupy more space in memory than the strict sum
of its fields would suggest. In the illustration, you can see extra
bytes (often represented as 0xCC or 0xBB in typical examples)
placed between fields to ensure alignment boundaries are
The GCC-specific __attribute__((packed)) is a compiler directive that
instructs GCC to remove any extra padding that it would normally
insert. When you declare a struct with __attribute__((packed)), each
field is placed immediately after the previous one, without alignment
Because no padding is inserted, the struct’s memory usage corresponds
exactly to the sum of its fields. This is particularly useful when working
with low-level protocols or hardware registers, where the layout of bits
and bytes must match a specific format. However, accessing unaligned
fields can sometimes incur performance penalties on certain
architectures, and in some cases, unaligned accesses might even cause
hardware exceptions. Therefore, you should use
Another way to control struct alignment is to use the #pragma
Here, the #pragma pack(push, 1) directive sets the new
alignment boundary to 1 byte, effectively telling the compiler
not to insert any padding. After the struct declaration,
#pragma pack(pop) restores the previous packing alignment.
This approach is not limited to GCC—it is recognized by
several compilers on different platforms. As with
unaligned accesses, so it should be used only when you
genuinely need to match a specific memory layout.
